Award.AwardTitle: Investigating DNA Mismatch Repair Through Single-Molecule Approaches

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
During DNA synthesis in living cells, potential for erroneous incorporation of nucleobases (e.g. introduction of a mismatch such as a thymine instead of a cytosine across from a guanine) is as high as 10% per nucleotide. These pro-mutagenic DNA alterations need to be removed through post-replication mismatch repair (MMR) systems. Malfunction of MMR has disastrous consequences. Even though tremendous progress has been made in elucidating DNA mismatch repair, mainly through biochemical studies, many critically important details of DNA repair mechanisms remain obscure and controversial, even for bacterial (E. coli) MMR system, which is the simplest and best characterized. This is because MMR involves an orchestrated activity of many proteins, which form transient complexes that are difficult to monitor in real time. In the previous project, atomic force microscopy (AFM) was used to directly visualize and examine the behavior of MutS, the key E.coli MMR protein that detects mismatched bases. Those AFM results, which reconciled the main features of previous, mutually exclusive models, provided new insights into the mechanism by which E.coli MMR is initiated. The main goal of the current research is to further unravel the mechanism of E. coli mismatch repair through the application of a suite of single-molecule techniques such as AFM,Optical Tweezers (OT) and single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer (SMFRET). Specifically, AFM imaging and volumetric measurements will be used to examine the structure of MutS tetramers and MutS complexes with MutL to determine the oligomeric status of both proteins in ternary complexes with heteroduplex DNA in the absence and presence of adenine nucleotides. AFM force spectroscopy will be used to measure the interactions within MutS dimers as well as the effect of adenine nucleotides on these interactions, while optical tweezers will be used to measure similar interactions within MutS tetramers as well as between MutS tetramers and DNA. MutS-controlled DNA looping mechanisms and pathways will be thoroughly examined using Optical Tweezers. SM-FRET will be used to follow, in real time, the position of the MMR proteins relative to key DNA sites (the mismatch site and strand signal site) and the distance and contact between these key DNA sites will be probed during the MMR reaction by all three techniques through mechanical and optical (fluorescence) detection. These single-molecule approaches will test a new MMR signaling model, in which the mismatch site and the site of DNA incision are brought into contact by the concerted work of two MutS dimers through a DNA looping-sliding mechanism. These approaches promise to unravel the details of the MMR mechanism that so far have proved very difficult to elucidate by traditional methods. The new results will significantly expand the knowledge base about one of the key mechanisms that is responsible for the maintenance of genomic stability and will lay the groundwork for future studies of eukaryotic MMR including human MMR. Methodologies developed for this model system may prove useful for studying other DNA repair systems and more generally to investigate protein-protein and DNA-protein interactions.

Broader impacts. This project will provide an exciting education and research opportunity for two graduate students and one undergraduate student. Because the project crosses several disciplines (biophysics, biochemistry, molecular biology, mechanics, single-molecule instrumentation) it will provide a rich learning experience for all people involved, junior and senior researchers alike. It will expose engineering students to important problems at the interface between modern biology and nanoscience. One of the graduate students involved will visit South Korea to receive training in sophisticated single-molecule optical methods to be used in this research. This international exchange will be beneficial to expanding international collaborations between leading US and foreign research and educational institutions. The potential benefit to society is in the increase in fundamental knowledge of mechanisms by which pre-mutagenic lesions are repaired in DNA. Outreach activities will involve K-12 students, their teachers and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DNA plays key roles in cellular life by storing the hereditary information and instructions for producing proteins, which perform most of the cellular functions. During their lifetime, cells divide, and during every cell division the whole cellular DNA needs to be duplicated through the process of DNA replication. Although almost perfect and equipped with the proof reading ability, the replication machinery occasionally makes copy errors and places a wrong nucleobase (one of the four “DNA letters” e.g. A, C, G, T) in the daughter DNA strand opposite to the mother strand, creating a mismatch, such as T-G, when a G base is incorporated into the daughter strand in front of the T base (within the mother strand) instead of the correct A base. This event produces a T-G mismatch replacing the correct T-A match. Upon a subsequent DNA replication cycle, even if the cellular machinery works perfectly well, DNA duplication will produce a correct match in one DNA molecule (the T-A match will be restored) but by copying the “old daughter” strand it will create a new “correct granddaughter strand” with the match C-G that was never present in the original DNA, thus creating a mutation that replaced the original T-A match with a new C-G match. Accumulation of such mutations would quickly compromise the information stored in the DNA and could (and does) lead to diseases, such as cancer.

To further guard DNA information integrity, all cells possess additional mechanisms for identifying new mismatches and correcting them by removing the offensive nucleobase (G in the example above) and replacing it with A. This function is carried out by the mismatch repair (MMR) cellular machinery involving many proteins, most notably MutS, MutL and Mut H. Even though a tremendous research effort that identified the key components of the MMR system and their main biochemical functions (a Nobel prize in 2015) has been carried out up to now, still many questions remain unanswered about the mechanism of mismatch repair, such as how mismatches are detected, and how different proteins interact with each other and with DNA to repair mismatches.

The main goal of this Project has been to further elucidate the mechanism of E. coli mismatch repair (the best recognized MMR system so far) by using a set of new biophysical techniques that can directly visualize individual protein and DNA molecules, as well as complexes of these molecules, when they interact. Most important to the project was the technique of atomic force microscopy (AFM) that creates topographical images of proteins and DNA with sub-molecular resolution. 

Using AFM, hundreds of DNA and MutS, MutL and MutH images were acquired and analyzed, and for the first time those images directly captured functional complexes of the three proteins on the DNA. These images revealed heterogeneity of possible complexes and captured new important functions for the MutS protein, such as positioning of MutL and MutH at the correct signal sites on the DNA to initiate DNA repair. Also, confirming earlier results, MutS and MutL were found to produce DNA loops connecting the specific DNA signal site to the location of the mismatch site to provide the system with the orientation in which repair needs to proceed. The analyses of these experiments also suggested a novel MMR hypothesis, which assumes that MutSLH complexes, possibly first identify the DNA signal site and later search for the mismatch site to connect the two, which is opposite to what researchers considered so far.

Using a novel approach which allows inserting engineered (synthetic) mismatches directly into bacterial DNA undergoing the replication process, it was possible to capture the efficiency of DNA MMR under various conditions. These experiments identified a new MMR mechanism, which may co-exist with the mechanism considered so far, with the new mechanism not requiring the protein MutH, but using MutS tetramers, MutL and possibly DNA looping as a primary means to initiate mismatch repair. These observations seem to confirm one of the original hypotheses of this Project assuming the importance of DNA looping for the MMR reaction to proceed. Altogether, this project for the first time directly visualized functional complexes of MutS+MutL+MutH initiating the MMR reaction and identified a new, MutH-independent component in the cellular MMR machinery that warrants further studies.

 

The results of this study were presented at 10 conferences and published in 4 peer-reviewed journal publications with two additional reports being under revision, while one Patent application is pending. This Project also created a new sophisticated instrument based on optical microscopy that allows studies of mismatch repair by capturing light signals from labeled MMR proteins and labeled DNA. Altogether, the project trained one post-doctoral associate, two PhD students and four undergraduate students contributing to a new cadre of researchers familiar with the nanotechnology and DNA biochemical problems and equipped with skills to address them.
